headline: Climate Change Comes to the Tetons
snippet: In one of North America’s most stunning mountain ranges, melting glaciers and warmer temperatures are raising fears of ecological tipping points.
lead_paragraph: On the wall of my hotel room here at the Jackson Lake Lodge in Moran, Wyo., there is a framed photograph of the spectacular Teton Range taken during the 1950s.

headline: Climate Change Is Making ‘Last Chance Tourism’ More Popular, and Riskier
snippet: More tourists are eager to visit vanishing glaciers and ice caves, but warming is also making the sites unstable.
lead_paragraph: An American tourist was visiting an ice cave in one of Europe’s largest national parks last month when a frozen arch collapsed, killing him and injuring his girlfriend.

headline: Court Orders South Korea to Take Stronger Action on Climate Change
snippet: A ruling by the Constitutional Court declared the nation’s current measures insufficient and a violation of the rights of future generations.
lead_paragraph: A top South Korean court on Thursday ruled the nation’s measures for fighting climate change insufficient for protecting the rights of citizens, and ordered the government to set firm carbon-reduction targets for 2031 and beyond. It is the first climate litigation ruling of its kind in Asia.

headline: Climate Change Can Cause Bridges to ‘Fall Apart Like Tinkertoys,’ Experts Say
snippet: Extreme heat and flooding are accelerating the deterioration of bridges, engineers say, posing a quiet but growing threat.
lead_paragraph: On a 95-degree day this summer, New York City’s Third Avenue Bridge, connecting the Bronx and Manhattan, got stuck in the open position for hours. As heat and flooding scorched and scoured the Midwest, a steel railroad bridge connecting Iowa with South Dakota collapsed under surging waters. In Lewiston, Maine, a bridge closed after the pavement buckled from fluctuating temperatures.

headline: In Threatened Island Nation, Pope Hears Plea for Climate Action
snippet: Pope Francis is visiting Papua New Guinea, which has been exploited for its natural resources and is imperiled by rising sea levels.
lead_paragraph: In the Pacific island nation of Papua New Guinea, hundreds of people may soon have to abandon their homes, pushed inland by the rising sea. Hundreds more were buried in a devastating landslide this year. Around the country, intensive logging is shrinking the island’s lush rainforests, and mine tailings have polluted its rivers.

headline: U.S. Election Looms Over Climate Talks with China
snippet: Experts believe the outcome of the race for the White House could determine how ambitious China’s climate efforts will be.
lead_paragraph: As John Podesta, President Biden’s climate envoy, wraps up three days of talks in Beijing, China’s willingness to fight global warming could depend on the outcome of this fall’s presidential election in the United States, energy experts said.

headline: Biden’s Top Climate Negotiator to Visit China This Week
snippet: John Podesta is expected to push for China to set more ambitious greenhouse gas targets.
lead_paragraph: John Podesta, President Biden’s top climate diplomat, is traveling to Beijing on Tuesday where he is expected to press Chinese leaders to make more ambitious plans to cut the greenhouse gas emissions that are driving climate change.

headline: The Killer Climate Disaster That Has No Name
snippet: Heat waves are America’s deadliest weather events. It’s time we name them.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the heat dome that settled over Washington and Oregon in 2021, leading to thousands of hospitalizations and over 600 estimated fatalities? Or last summer’s heat wave in Phoenix, when the temperature hit or exceeded 110 degrees for 31 straight days, accounting for most of Maricopa County’s 645 heat-related deaths in 2023?

headline: It’s Been the Hottest Summer on Record, European Officials Say
snippet: The excessive heat worldwide suggests the full year will also be a record-breaker, according to Copernicus, the E.U. agency that tracks global warming.
lead_paragraph: The summer of “brat,” the Paris Olympics and political conventions may be winding down, but the heat in 2024 is still going strong.

headline: My Teenage Son Thinks the World Is Falling Apart. I’ve Changed How I Talk to Him About It.
snippet: My instinct to minimize what is happening in much of the world was robbing my sons of a sense of urgency that demands their attention.
lead_paragraph: Within our marriage, my wife and I have a clash of cultures, which means we talk to our kids quite differently about the state of the world and its future. We play somewhat typecast roles. I’m the upbeat dad from America; she’s the no-nonsense mom from Poland. We’ve created two different schools of child-rearing; it’s pretty much Disney versus the Iron Curtain.

headline: Shocked by Extreme Storms, a Maine Fishing Town Fights to Save Its Waterfront
snippet: After two devastating storms hit Stonington in January, plans are multiplying to raise and fortify wharves, roads and buildings. But will that be enough?

headline: The Electric Vehicle Future Is Coming. Just a Little More Slowly.
snippet: Though large automakers are delaying their plans to introduce new all-electric models, the E.V. industry is still the future, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The race to electrify America’s cars is looking more like a slog these days. In the past few months, several automakers announced plans to pull back on introducing new electric models or have scaled back some of their decarbonization goals.

headline: Kuwait Is Awash in Oil Money. But It Can’t Keep the Power on.
snippet: The Persian Gulf nation has instituted rolling blackouts to cope with surging summer electricity demand, stirring frustration among citizens.
lead_paragraph: Kuwait, perched atop around 6 percent of global oil reserves, is one of the world’s wealthiest states and a major energy exporter.

headline: Rafting a Western River With the Next Generation
snippet: On a family trip in Montana, a father shares a tradition with his two sons even as climate change threatens the certainty of the rivers he grew up running.
lead_paragraph: Rivers soak into your bones.

headline: A Heat Pump Can Cut Your Emissions. But Read This Before You Switch.
snippet: A Times climate reporter recounts his journey to switch his home’s HVAC system to a climate-friendly heat pump.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard the pitch for heat pumps: They can cut greenhouse gas emissions by more than half compared with traditional gas-powered HVAC systems. They’ll save you money because you’ll pay less for energy. And, thanks to the tax credits passed by Congress in 2022, they’re more affordable than ever. What’s not to love?

headline: Mr. Greedy, Father to Many African Penguins at Maryland Zoo, Dies at 33
snippet: An African penguin who left many offspring in his long life, he belonged to the largest colony of the aquatic bird species in North America, according to the zoo.
lead_paragraph: The popular African penguin known as Mr. Greedy, a fixture of the Maryland Zoo who had sired many offspring and left “an astounding 230 descendants” over five generations, has died after an age-related decline in his health, the zoo said in a statement.

headline: Solar Farms Have a Superpower Beyond Clean Energy
snippet: The sites fight climate change and can help with another global crisis: the collapse of nature. But so far, efforts to nurture wildlife habitat have been spotty.
lead_paragraph: It’s not your average solar farm.

headline: They’re Sizing Up Earth’s Lungs. It Takes Tape Measures and Tree Climbing.
snippet: A small team in a remote corner of Colombia is surveying every tree in an effort to better understand how much planet-warming carbon the Amazon actually stores.
lead_paragraph: With the help of a small rope tied around his ankles, Eugenio Sánchez, lithe at age 50, shimmied himself all the way up a towering tree like a human inchworm, his chest heaving from the exertion, just to pick a few leaves.

headline: Two Years After Deadly Floods Hit Pakistan, It’s Happening Again
snippet: Millions of people still recovering from the devastation of 2022 are bracing for the possibility of losing what they’ve rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: One recent evening, as heavy monsoon rains pounded down, Fauzia and her extended family of 15 huddled under a makeshift tent, its top patched with large plastic sheets.

headline: Climate-Friendly Meat? Regulators Tighten Scrutiny of Label Buzzwords.
snippet: The new guidelines from the Agriculture Department encourage third-party assessments of environment-related claims, which have come under fire.
lead_paragraph: Climate-smart. Regeneratively grown. Sustainable.

headline: Record Rainfall Spoils Crops in China, Rattling Its Leaders
snippet: Some vegetables cost more than they have in five years. Top Chinese officials have made a point of showing that they’re doing something about it.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of drought, farmers in the typically arid agricultural belt in northern China were ill prepared for the torrential rain that inundated fields earlier this summer and decimated their crops of eggplant, cucumbers and cabbage.

headline: Was This the Summer European Tourism Reached a Breaking Point?
snippet: Overwhelmed destinations made high-season visitors the targets of a major tourism backlash. Heat waves and fires only added to the pressure.
lead_paragraph: Protesters staging hunger strikes against tourism developments. Local officials threatening to cut off water to illegal vacation rentals. Residents spraying tourists with water pistols.

headline: I Swore Off Air-Conditioning, and You Can, Too
snippet: The more time we can spend outside or inside without the air-conditioner blasting, the better prepared we’ll be — both to slow climate change and to adapt to it.
lead_paragraph: Whenever people ask me how my wife and I have endured 25 Kansas summers almost entirely without air-conditioning, I like to say we do it because air-conditioning makes it too hot outside. We’re not ascetics, Luddites or misers; we just want to keep living comfortably, indoors and out.

headline: Business Group Sues Texas Officials Over Law That Shields Oil Industry
snippet: The suit challenges a measure that prohibits state entities like retirement funds from doing business with firms that “boycott energy companies.”
lead_paragraph: A liberal business group sued Texas officials this week in a major challenge to a 2021 law that bars state entities from doing business with investment firms that the state comptroller says are boycotting energy companies.

headline: When the Flash Flood Comes With Godlike Velocity, Why Do I Stay and Watch?
snippet: This series of floods didn’t force us to leave. But the next ones might.
lead_paragraph: Something is coming. I smell it before I hear it, and I hear it before I see it.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Our Reporting on Toxic Sludge Fertilizer
snippet: The Times dug into the widespread use of sewage sludge as fertilizer, which is sometimes heavily contaminated by “forever chemicals.”
lead_paragraph: For decades, the government has encouraged farmers across the United States to spread sewage sludge on their cropland and pastures. But now there’s a growing awareness that sludge fertilizer can contain heavy concentrations of “forever chemicals” linked to cancer, birth defects and other health risks.

headline: 100-Plus Tons of Dead Fish, and Their Smell, Swamp a Greek Port City
snippet: The mass deaths of the fish were most likely caused by climate change. The vacation area and its businesses have been suffering since.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in central Greece said on Thursday that they had dredged more than 100 tons of dead fish from the waters around the port of Volos, a scenic summer destination, after a mass die-off of fish that is believed to be linked to climate change.

headline: Silicon Valley Wants to Fight Fires With Fire
snippet: How some high-tech entrepreneurs are trying to use new forms of technology to solve the problem of mega-wildfires in the age of climate change.
lead_paragraph: This is the tinder box of the Sierra Nevada. It’s early June, the temperature is 97 degrees Fahrenheit and the air shimmers over dead trees choked in brush. In the Stanislaus National Forest, logging roads wind through firs and ponderosa pines, past 20-foot-tall burn piles — tons of scrap wood not worth bringing to a sawmill. They’ve been assembled by workers on the front line of the fight against forest fires: a timber crew thinning these woods for the U.S. Forest Service and a tech start-up that’s trying to automate the enormous machines the crew relies on.

headline: Turbine Blades Have Piled Up in Landfills. A Solution May Be Coming.
snippet: Wind power has a waste problem that has been difficult to solve. Turbine blades made from a new plant-based material could make them recyclable.
lead_paragraph: The blades on the newest wind turbines sweep an area longer than a football field and are nearly impossible to recycle.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Extreme Weather Is Increasing Risk of Collapse for U.S. Bridges
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s getting so hot that the pieces that hold the concrete and steel, those bridges can literally fall apart like Tinkertoys.”

headline: Netanyahu Unwavering on Cease-Fire, and Putin Visits Mongolia
snippet: Plus, battling mpox in Congo.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Corrections: Aug. 31, 2024
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a court ruling in South Korea that ordered the government to take stronger action on Climate Change misstated an aspect of the court’s ruling. It gave the National Assembly until the end of February 2026, not February 2025, to revise the Carbon Neutral Act.

headline: Pope, 87, Embarks on ‘Physical Test’ in Grueling Asia Tour
snippet: The 11-day trip, a signal that Francis does not intend to slow down, requires nearly 45 hours of air travel and meetings in tropical climates.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis left Monday on an 11-day trip to the Asia-Pacific region, the longest and among the most complicated of his tenure. It could be particularly challenging for Francis, 87, who has been using a wheelchair and battling health problems.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 11, 2024
snippet: America isn’t making electricity the way it did two decades ago. How have energy sources changed since 2001?
lead_paragraph: The above graph of the power produced by energy source between 2001 and 2023 was previously published in a New York Times article. Comparable graphs were published for each of the 50 states.

headline: Surprising New Research Links Infant Mortality to Crashing Bat Populations
snippet: Without bats to eat insects, farmers turned to more pesticides, a study found. That appears to have increased infant deaths.
lead_paragraph: The connections are commonsense but the conclusion is shocking.

headline: Only the First Amendment Can Protect Students, Campuses and Speech
snippet: Colleges and universities are democracy’s greatest arsenal. They do not need the unanimity of the graveyard.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, protests at numerous American universities, prompted by the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, produced fierce debates over freedom of speech on campus.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
snippet: Protests and work stoppages in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rebuffed calls from allies, protesters and the families of hostages for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza that would facilitate the return of hostages, doubling down on his refusal to agree to a truce that would involve Israel’s withdrawal from the territory.

headline: 100 Degrees at Midnight: California Coast Swelters in ‘Concerning’ Heat
snippet: Temperatures in the region were forecast to remain high into the weekend, with more than 31 million people under excessive heat warnings.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures hovered above 100 degrees Fahrenheit along parts of the California coast early Friday, creating unbearable conditions past midnight as officials warned that the excessive heat would last through the weekend.

headline: Assessing JD Vance’s Appeals to the Middle Class on the Campaign Trail
snippet: The Republican vice-presidential nominee has assailed Vice President Kamala Harris’s policies and positions with inaccurate claims.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee who rose to fame detailing his Appalachian roots in a best-selling memoir, has made appeals to working-class and middle-class voters a core tenet of his campaign messaging.

headline: Pedro Almodóvar, Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton on ‘The Room Next Door’
snippet: The director’s first English-language feature inspires talk of beauty, hope and more collaborations.
lead_paragraph: At Monday night’s Venice after-party for “The Room Next Door,” Pedro Almodóvar beamed at his leading ladies as they beamed back.

headline: Naked Emperors and Crypto Campaign Cash
snippet: Why a mostly useless industry dominates corporate political spending.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time there was an emperor who loved being fashion-forward. So he was receptive to some fast-talking tailors who promised to make him a suit out of new, high-technology fabric — a suit so comfortable that it would feel as if he were wearing nothing at all. “Fortune favors the brave,” they told him.

headline: The Hurricane Season Was Supposed to Be Busy. What Happened?
snippet: An intermission in hurricanes across the Atlantic has people wondering where the predicted storms are.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through an Atlantic hurricane season that forecasters expected would be one of the most active on record, there has been a considerable interlude in storms during what is typically the busiest portion of the season, leaving observers to wonder if the forecast was a bust — or if the worst may be yet to come.

headline: Is Hydrogen the Missing Piece in Solving the World’s Energy Puzzle?
snippet: A unique hydrogen ecosystem strategy is making the prospect of a hydrogen society increasingly feasible.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Reshuffles its Government
snippet: Plus, Daniel Dae Kim takes a risk.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, laid out plans for the broadest reshuffling of his cabinet since the war began two years ago. The country’s foreign minister was one of half a dozen senior officials who offered their resignation yesterday, and a new list of minsters is expected today.

headline: Hunter Biden Pleaded Guilty
snippet: Also, teenage vaping dropped to a 10-year low. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, pleaded guilty today to nine federal tax charges in Los Angeles. He told his lawyers that he did not want to subject his family to another round of humiliation after his wrenching gun trial in Delaware nearly three months ago.

headline: How Harris Wins (and Trump and the Republicans Blow It)
snippet: To understand Harris’s success, you have to think about Marie Kondo and her ruthless minimalism about clutter.
lead_paragraph: It’s Nov. 6, 2024, the morning after Election Day.

headline: Walz’s Pennsylvania Campaign Swing Underscores Challenges in the Battleground
snippet: With his daughter, Hope, in tow, Gov. Tim Walz made stops in red-leaning parts of a state that both parties see as critical to victory, but his events featured limited interactions with voters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Thursday capped two days of crisscrossing Pennsylvania, talking up Vice President Kamala Harris’s experience, taking shots at former President Donald J. Trump and making his now familiar pleas to voters that they fight for freedom with optimism.

headline: Friday Briefing
snippet: Kamala Harris’s interview with CNN.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Trump Floats Coverage Mandate for I.V.F. Treatment
snippet: The former president, who frequently takes credit for helping to overturn Roe v. Wade, has been trying to reposition himself on the issue of reproductive access
lead_paragraph: The week after Democrats spent much of their national convention attacking him over his position on abortion rights and reproductive health, former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that he would require insurance companies or the federal government to pay for all costs associated with in vitro fertilization treatments if he is elected in November.

headline: Yuval Noah Harari: What Happens When the Bots Compete for Your Love?
snippet: The world will soon be flooded with fake humans.
lead_paragraph: Democracy is a conversation. Its function and survival depend on the available information technology. For most of history, no technology existed for holding large-scale conversations among millions of people. In the premodern world, democracies existed only in small city-states like Rome and Athens, or in even smaller tribes. Once a polity grew large, the democratic conversation collapsed, and authoritarianism remained the only alternative.
